replies.bodyText:
Taking it a step further, why do we need any of those *Infrastructure classes? They seem to add mostly complexity, for no real benefit. PostgresInfrastructure in particular has quite a few methods which don't seem to be used at all even. The Testcontainers API is simple and easy enough, tests can just interact with it, we don't need (and should not have) another abstraction on top of it.
Re ApicurioConnectContainer, I don't think there's need for that either; we should just have a method enableApicurioConverters() on the existing DebeziumContainer which sets the right environment variable for enabling those converters (see description of the Debezium image in our docker-containers repo, and the Apicurio Compose file of the tutorial example).
We could have an ApicurioRegistryContainer though, which e.g. provides that waitingFor() logic OOTB.
replies.author: gunnarmorling

replies.bodyText:
The *Interface class was meant for cases where we don't need any custom GenericContainer<?> extension (like the DebeziumContainer) and to avoid dependency to Testcontainers internal API. It just provided slightly customized default images using the external API and manages when we need concurrent Postgres versions in tests.
But it's valid we could also create a new *Container class instead. But then we are architecturally bound to Testcontainers' internal (GenericContainer) API changes.
replies.author: rk3rn3r

replies.bodyText: Yes, I'm not concerned about changes to the GenericContainer API.
replies.author: gunnarmorling

timeline.bodyText:
That's not needed actually (see my other comment below), current Debezium versions contain those converters already, it's only a matter of enabling them by means of an env var. I.e. this class here should not be needed, and instead a test wishing to use Connect/DBZ with the Apicurio converters would do it like so:
public static DebeziumContainer debeziumContainer = new DebeziumContainer()
            .withNetwork(network)
            .withKafka(kafkaContainer)
            .withLogConsumer(new Slf4jLogConsumer(LOGGER))
            .enableApicurioConverters() // <----
            .dependsOn(kafkaContainer);

replies.bodyText: What is this duplicated code exactly? Keep in mind sometimes some duplication can be worthwhile if it aids to understandability of the code. If I look at four lines of TC set-up code I instantly know what this is about, whereas some custom *Infrastructure class forces me to learn about its concepts and abstractions. We can do the DebeziumPostgreSQLContainer perhaps, but I'm curious to see what it actually would encapsulate, apart from the container image name.

replies.bodyText:
What is this here?

The re-use of this code across repo boundaries, due to the maintenance burden and lifecycle questions associated to it. Again, abstraction is not a means to an end, I'm all for duplication if it is conceptually simpler. We already spent more time and mental energy discussing this then this will ever pay off.

I suggested making PostgresInfrastructure a DebeziumPostgreSQLContainer extends PostgreSQLContainer<>. Is that okay?

If it solely does encapsulate this code:
public static PostgreSQLContainer<?> postgresContainer = new PostgreSQLContainer<>(POSTGRES_DOCKER_IMAGE_NAME)
            .withNetwork(network)
            .withNetworkAliases("postgres");

Then, no, I don't think we should do it. It's not worth any abstraction and interaction with the plain TC API is more idiomatic and comprehensible.
